---
title: Creating a brand.yml with an LLM
author: Garrick Aden-Buie
description: |
  Learn how to create a brand.yml file using a large language model (LLM) like
  ChatGPT or Claude. This guide includes a system prompt you can use to teach
  LLMs about brand.yml and some tips and tricks for getting the highest quality
  results from an LLM.
date: 2024-11-15
image: feature.webp
---

Extracting color values, fonts and logos from brand guidelines can be a tedious process.
Thankfully, large language models (LLMs) are great at moving words and information around and can do the tedious work for you!

Because **brand.yml** is a _brand_[^1] new project, large language models like [OpenAI's ChatGPT](https://chat.openai.com/chat), [Anthropic's Claude](https://claude.ai/) and others haven't learned the syntax (yet).

[^1]: Pun intended. Sorry, not sorry.

## Teaching LLMs about brand.yml

Fortunately, it's relatively easy to teach an LLM everything it needs to know about brand.yml.
We've created a [simple markdown file explaining brand.yml](brand-yml.prompt.txt)[^llms-txt] that you can copy and paste into a chat interface or that you can use as [a system prompt](https://github.com/mustvlad/ChatGPT-System-Prompts#what-are-system-prompts).

[^llms-txt]: This file is also served at <https://posit-dev.github.io/brand-yml/.well-known/llms.txt>.

::: {.callout-tip title="brand.yml Prompt" collapse="true"}
Copy the code block below and paste it into a chat interface or use it as a system prompt.

`````{.markdown}
{{< include brand-yml.prompt.txt >}}
`````
:::

If you've copied the above text into the chat (as opposed to using it as a system prompt), make sure that you follow up with additional instructions, for example:

```{.markdown}
Create a _brand.yml for {company} using the following context from {company}'s' brand guidelines

<!-- paste text or screenshots from typography, color, logos sections -->
```

## Some tips and tricks

### Copy and paste from brand guidelines

In general, if you can copy and paste entire sections from your brand guidelines, that approach works better than uploading screenshots.
If your brand guidelines are designed in PDF and are not plain text, you can take screenshots or try uploading the brand guidelines directly.

As a last resort, find a webpage or document that serves as a complete demonstration of your brand's design and include a screenshot.
In my experience, ChatGPT and Claude can get fairly close to your brand from a simple screenshot.

### Ask for alternative fonts

Many brands use proprietary fonts that aren't freely available online.
When translating typographic choices from brand guidelines, LLMs tend to include placeholder YAML for these font files assuming that you'll be able to download them.

It can be helpful to ask a follow-up question to request publicly-available font substitutes using either [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com) or [Bunny Fonts](https://fonts.bunny.net) (a GDPR-compliant alternative to Google Fonts).

```{.markdown}
Find alternative fonts that match {company}'s fonts using Google Fonts.
```

I've been impressed with the ability of LLMs to pick reasonable font substitutes with this simple level of prompting.

### Ask for Bootstrap color aliases

Both brand guidelines and LLMs tend to use creative language when naming colors, e.g. `tea-green`, `amethyst`, `raisin` and `hunter` (color names used in [Dell's brand guidelines](https://www.dell.com/en-us/lp/brand-guidelines-color)).
On the other hand, many web frameworks like Bootstrap have hooks for [simple, common color names](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.0/customize/color/) such as `blue`, `green`, `yellow`, `purple`, etc.

It can be helpful to ask a follow-up question to make sure that your `_brand.yml` includes aliases for these color names.

```{.markdown}
Update `color.palette` to include aliases for Bootstrap's
primary colors drawing from the brand's color palette.
```

### Try `_brand.yml` in a live example

Once you have the initial `_brand.yml` file from the LLM, you can try it out in a live Shiny app on [shinylive.io](https://shinylive.io/py/examples).
Shinylive apps run directly in your browser and do not require any installation.

We've created an example app using Shiny's branded theming.
Copy the `_brand.yml` from the LLM and replace the `_brand.yml` content in the app editor.
